With the clouds moving down in the background itll look like they’re falling, and in order for him to move up you could switch out the sprite with the parachute one when you move your mouse up

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:49, topic:408673”]-__________- yes

public class Player {

//Rectangle to represent the player
[b]Rectangle player;
static int x;
static int y;[/b]
  • why did you make it static?

I also gave you ways so that you wouldn’t need to hard-code the values of the screen size in, but then you went around and changed that back too…[/quote]

I think it was something about the getX() and getY() methods. Sometimes they were returning 0 for no reason. Like it would print out the actual coordinates and then two zeros for the coordinates. So i tried making it static and it worked. I think that’s why, I’m not on that computer to test it anyway…

Also I’m still using my code. I haven’t touched your code. It’s sitting in the test package of the project in netbeans.

Read full topic

-__________- yes

public class Player {

//Rectangle to represent the player
[b]Rectangle player;
static int x;
static int y;[/b]
  • why did you make it static?

I also gave you ways so that you wouldn’t need to hard-code the values of the screen size in, but then you went around and changed that back too…

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square

It’s still my code. Just the updated version of mine. I don’t want to implement the ideas of your code just yet because I don’t completely understand them yet.
[/quote]…
But doing it the way you have it virtually ruins the point, and is not very good technique D:

But what’s wrong with the way I did it?
[/quote]It’s redundant redundant :([/quote]

oic wut u did der.

Anyway, what’s redundant about it? is there just no need for some of the code I have written or what?

It only makes a difference in readability. Iirc, imports are cleared up when the program is compiled, so using java.awt.* would compile to the same as java.awt.Class.[/quote]

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

@the import shit
It only makes a difference in readability. Iirc, imports are cleared up when the program is compiled, so using java.awt.* would compile to the same as java.awt.Class.

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

LilXCj:

Or you could just import the classes you NEED. Since I believe importing a entire section (awt) would just make the game run slower IMO. It might just be me.

no, there’s no overhead in importing everything in a certain package however you might end up with dependency clashes if you import the whole of two packages and they both have classes with the same name. it’s best just to import the classes you need.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

LilXCj:

Or you could just import the classes you NEED. Since I believe importing a entire section (awt) would just make the game run slower IMO. It might just be me.

That’s what I’m doing? Whenever I use a new class I always do right click -> fix imports which will add that specific class import. I don’t usually import the whole thing unless I’m being lazy.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

Or you could just import the classes you NEED. Since I believe importing a entire section (awt) would just make the game run slower IMO. It might just be me.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“bballin24, post:38, topic:408673”]import java.awt.BorderLayout; import java.awt.Color; import java.awt.Font; import java.awt.Graphics; import java.awt.Graphics2D; import java.awt.Image; import java.awt.event.ActionEvent; import java.awt.event.ActionListener; import java.awt.event.KeyAdapter; import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;

Instead of having all the awt individual classes imported you could go use import java.awt.*; I usually use that if im going to use more than 3 classes from the same package. Just makes your work a little easier[/quote]

Netbeans = right click -> fix imports

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Avoid the Square
item.dc:creator: @bballin24 bballin24
item.description:
@bballin24 wrote:

import java.awt.BorderLayout; import java.awt.Color; import java.awt.Font; import java.awt.Graphics; import java.awt.Graphics2D; import java.awt.Image; import java.awt.event.ActionEvent; import java.awt.event.ActionListener; import java.awt.event.KeyAdapter; import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;

Instead of having all the awt individual classes imported you could go use import java.awt.*; I usually use that if im going to use more than 3 classes from the same package. Just makes your work a little easier

Read full topic
